description: flat square bottle on a tapered foot, square neck and mouth, wide rim; metallic and blue glaze at narrow sides, blue-white ground with open and dying flower at widest sides
text: In the Japanese collective psyche, Kawai Kanjiro_ ranks as highly as Hamada Sho_ji, but he is little known in the West since he refused all official honors (including designation as a "Living National Treasure") and never traveled to Europe or the United States. He established a studio and kiln in Kyoto and there created works that were as innovative for their sculptural shapes as for their masterful glazes. His slab-mold bottles, such as this example, are especially admired as they showcase his freely painted designs in cobalt blue, iron brown, and copper red.
